00011 #define GEOGRAPHICLIB_GNOMONIC_HPP "$Id: Gnomonic.hpp 6845 2010-07-21 10:23:46Z karney $"
00012 
00013 #include "GeographicLib/Geodesic.hpp"
00014 #include "GeographicLib/Constants.hpp"
00015 
00016 namespace GeographicLib {
00017 
00018   /**
00019    * \brief %Gnomonic Projection.
00020    *
00021    * %Gnomonic projection centered at an arbitrary position \e C on the
00022    * ellipsoid.  The projection of \e P is defined as follows: compute the
00023    * geodesic line from \e C to \e P; compute the reduced length \e m12,
00024    * geodesic scale \e M12, and \e rho = \e m12/\e M12; finally \e x = \e rho
00025    * sin \e azi1; \e y = \e rho cos \e azi1, where \e azi1 is the azimuth of
00026    * the geodesic at \e C.  The Forward and Reverse methods also return the
00027    * azimuth \e azi of the geodesic at \e P and reciprocal scale \e rk in the
00028    * azimuthal direction.  The scale in the radial direction if 1/\e
00029    * rk<sup>2</sup>.
00030    *
00031    * For a sphere, \e rho is reduces to \e a tan(\e s12/\e a), where \e s12 is
00032    * the length of the geodesic from \e C to \e P, and the gnomonic projection
00033    * has the property that all geodesics appear as straight lines.  For an
00034    * ellipsoid, this property holds only for geodesics interesting the centers.
00035    * However geodesic segments close to the center are approximately straight.
00036    *
00037    * Consider a geodesic segment of length \e l.  Let \e T be the point on the
00038    * geodesic closest to \e C the center of the projection and \e t be the
00039    * distance \e CT.  To lowest order, the maximum deviation (as a true
00040    * distance) of the corresponding gnomonic line segment (i.e., with the same
00041    * end points) from the geodesic is<br>
00042    * <br>
00043    * (\e K(T) - \e K(C)) \e l<sup>2</sup> \e t / 32.<br>
00044    * <br>
00045    * where \e K is the Gaussian curvature.
00046    *
00047    * This result applies for any surface.  For an allipsoid of revoluation,
00048    * consider all geodesics whose end points are within a distance \e r of \e
00049    * C.  For a given \e r, the deviation is maximum when the latitude of \e C
00050    * is 45<sup>o</sup>, when endpoints are a distance \e r away, and when their
00051    * azimuths from the center are +/- 45<sup>o</sup> or +/- 135<sup>o</sup>.
00052    * To lowest order in \e r and the flattening \e f, the deviation is \e f
00053    * (\e r/2\e a)<sup>3</sup> \e r.
00054    *
00055    * The conversions all take place using a GeographicLib::Geodesic object (by
00056    * default GeographicLib::Geodesic::WGS84).  For more information on
00057    * geodesics see \ref geodesic.
00058    *
00059    * <b>CAUTION:</b> The definition of this projection for a sphere is
00060    * standard.  However, there is no standard for how it should be extended to
00061    * an ellipsoid.  The choices are:
00062    * - Declare that the projection is undefined for an ellipsoid.
00063    * - Project to a tangent plane from the center of the ellipsoid.  This
00064    *   causes great ellipses to appear as straight lines in the projection;
00065    *   i.e., it generalizes the spherical great circle to a great ellipse.
00066    *   This was proposed by Roy Williams, Geometry of Navigation (Horwood,
00067    *   Chichester, 1998).
00068    * - Project to the conformal sphere with the constant of integration chosen
00069    *   so that the values of the latitude match for the center point and
00070    *   perform a central projection onto the plane tangent to the conformal
00071    *   sphere at the center point.  This causes normal sections through the
00072    *   center point to appear as straight lines in the projection; i.e., it
00073    *   generalizes the spherical great circle to a normal section.  This was
00074    *   proposed by I. G. Letoval'tsev, Generalization of the %Gnomonic
00075    *   Projection for a Spheroid and the Principal Geodetic Problems Involved
00076    *   in the Alignment of Surface Routes, Geodesy and Aerophotography (5),
00077    *   271-274 (1963).
00078    * - The projection given here.  This causes geodesics close to the center
00079    *   point to appear as straight lines in the projection; i.e., it
00080    *   generalizes the spherical great circle to a geodesic.
00081    **********************************************************************/
00082 
00083   class Gnomonic {
00084   private:
00085     typedef Math::real real;
00086     const Geodesic _earth;
00087     real _a, _f;
00088     static const real eps0, eps;
00089     static const int numit = 10;
00090   public:
00091 
00092     /**
00093      * Constructor for Gnomonic setting the Geodesic object to use
00094      * for geodesic calculations.  By default this uses the WGS84 ellipsoid.
00095      **********************************************************************/
00096     explicit Gnomonic(const Geodesic& earth = Geodesic::WGS84)
00097       throw()
00098       : _earth(earth)
00099       , _a(_earth.MajorRadius())
00100       , _f(_earth.InverseFlattening() ?
00101            1/std::abs(_earth.InverseFlattening()) : 0)
00102     {}
00103 
00104     /**
00105      * Convert from latitude \e lat (degrees) and longitude \e lon (degrees) to
00106      * gnomonic easting \e x (meters) and northing \e y (meters).  The center
00107      * of the projection is at latitude \e lat0 (degrees) and longitude \e lon0
00108      * (degrees).  Also return the azimuth \e azi (degrees) and the reciprocal
00109      * of the azimuthal scale \e rk.  \e lat0 and \e lat should be in the range
00110      * [-90, 90] and \e lon0 and \e lon should be in the range [-180, 360].
00111      * The scale of the projection is 1/\e rk<sup>2</sup> in the "radial"
00112      * direction, \e azi clockwise from true north, and is 1/\e rk in the
00113      * direction perpendicular to this.  If the point lies "over the horizon",
00114      * i.e., if \e rk <= 0, then NaNs are returned for \e x and \e y (the
00115      * correct values are returned for \e azi and \e rk).  A call to Forward
00116      * followed by a call to Reverse will return the original (\e lat, \e lon)
00117      * (to within roundoff) provided the point in not over the horizon.
00118      **********************************************************************/
00119     void Forward(real lat0, real lon0, real lat, real lon,
00120                  real& x, real& y, real& azi, real& rk) const throw();
00121 
00122     /**
00123      * Convert from gnomonic easting \e x (meters) and northing \e y (meters)
00124      * to latitude \e lat (degrees) and longitude \e lon (degrees).  The center
00125      * of the projection is at latitude \e lat0 (degrees) and longitude \e lon0
00126      * (degrees).  Also return the azimuth \e azi (degrees) and the reciprocal
00127      * of the azimuthal scale \e rk.  \e lat0 should be in the range [-90, 90]
00128      * and \e lon0 should be in the range [-180, 360].  \e lat will be in the
00129      * range [-90, 90] and \e lon will be in the range [-180, 180).  The scale
00130      * of the projection is 1/\e rk<sup>2</sup> in the "radial" direction, \e
00131      * azi clockwise from true north, and is 1/\e rk in the direction
00132      * perpendicular to this.  Even though all inputs should return a valid \e
00133      * lat and \e lon, it's possible that the procedure fails to converge for
00134      * very large \e x or \e y; in this case NaNs are returned for all the
00135      * output arguments.  A call to Reverse followed by a call to Forward will
00136      * return the original (\e x, \e y) (to roundoff).
00137      **********************************************************************/
00138     void Reverse(real lat0, real lon0, real x, real y,
00139                  real& lat, real& lon, real& azi, real& rk) const throw();
00140 
00141     /**
00142      * The major radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is that value of \e a
00143      * inherited from the Geodesic object used in the constructor.
00144      **********************************************************************/
00145     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return _earth.MajorRadius(); }
00146 
00147     /**
00148      * The inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is that value of \e r
00149      * inherited from the Geodesic object used in the constructor.  A value of
00150      * 0 is returned for a sphere (infinite inverse flattening).
00151      **********************************************************************/
00152     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw()
00153     { return _earth.InverseFlattening(); }
00154   };
00155 
00156 } // namespace GeographicLib
00157 
00158 #endif
